title: The dark history of IQ tests - Stefan C. Dombrowski

multiple-choice.question: Who designed a test for children who were struggling in school in France in 1905?
What does the term "g factor" refer to in the context of intelligence?

options.label: A
options.text: A specific type of cognitive ability

multiple-choice.question: How is an IQ score typically calculated?

options.label: A
options.text: By multiplying a person's age by their test score

options.label: B
options.text: By dividing a person's test score by their age and multiplying by 100

options.label: C
options.text: By adding a person's test score to their age

options.label: D
options.text: By subtracting a person's age from their test score

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the population scores within 15 points of 100 on an IQ test?
What was one of the first large-scale implementations of IQ testing?

options.label: A
options.text: In schools to identify gifted students

options.label: B
options.text: In the military to sort recruits and screen for officer training

options.label: C
options.text: In hospitals to diagnose psychiatric conditions

options.label: D
options.text: In workplaces to evaluate employee performance

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the idea that desirable and undesirable genetic traits can be controlled through selective breeding?
What was the result of the intersection of eugenics and IQ testing in the United States?

options.label: A
options.text: The creation of policies to support people with low IQ scores

options.label: B
options.text: The development of new treatments for psychiatric conditions

options.label: C
options.text: The forced sterilization of people with low IQ scores

options.label: D
options.text: The establishment of programs to improve education and healthcare

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the phenomenon of new generations scoring consistently higher on old IQ tests?
What is one of the current uses of IQ tests?

options.label: B
options.text: To identify intellectual disability and determine educational support

options.label: D
options.text: To screen for officer training in the military

multiple-choice.question: What do many researchers agree on regarding IQ testing?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is a perfect measure of intelligence

options.label: B
options.text: That it is a good way to categorize individuals by a single numerical score

options.label: C
options.text: That it does a good job of measuring reasoning and problem-solving skills, but not potential

title: The history of colonial America

multiple-choice.question: What is a colony?

options.label: A
options.text: A place that's settled by a group of people within their home country.

options.label: B
options.text: A place that's settled by a group of people outside their home country and belongs to or is ruled by that home country.

options.label: C
options.text: A place that's settled by a group of people outside their home country and is independent.

options.label: D
options.text: A place that's settled by a group of people within their home country and is independent.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following was a main reason people came to the New England colonies?

options.label: A
options.text: To make money and get rich.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main way people in the New England colonies made money?
What was unique about the way the New England colonies were governed?

options.label: A
options.text: They had a king who made all the decisions.

options.label: B
options.text: They had town meetings where people discussed issues.

options.label: C
options.text: They had a governor who made all the decisions.

options.label: D
options.text: They had a council of elders who made all the decisions.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main crop grown in the Southern colonies?
What was the main source of labor in the Southern colonies?
What was the climate like in the Middle colonies?
What was the main industry in the Middle colonies?
What was unique about the population of the Middle colonies?

options.label: C
options.text: They were diverse and included people from many different countries.

multiple-choice.question: What eventually became of the 13 colonies?

options.label: C
options.text: They were absorbed into other colonies.

options.label: D
options.text: They were abandoned and left uninhabited.

multiple-choice.question: What are the main parts of a story?

options.label: D
options.text: The end of the story where the conflict is resolved

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The most exciting part of the story where the conflict reaches its peak

options.label: D
options.text: The end of the story where the conflict is resolved

options.label: D
options.text: The most exciting part of the story where the conflict reaches its peak

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The character who opposes the main character

options.label: C
options.text: A supporting character who helps the main character

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The part of the story where the conflict starts to resolve

options.label: D
options.text: The end of the story where the conflict is resolved

multiple-choice.question: What is the rising action in a story?

options.label: B
options.text: The part of the story where the conflict builds up

options.label: C

title: The that song

multiple-choice.question: What is poetry?

options.label: A
options.text: A form of literature that uses factual language to convey information.

options.label: B
options.text: A form of literature that uses aesthetic and often symbolic language to evoke emotions and ideas.

options.label: C
options.text: A form of literature that uses only rhyming words.

options.label: D
options.text: A form of literature that is only written in free verse.

multiple-choice.question: What is a sonnet?

options.label: A
options.text: A short, three-line poem that originated in Japan.

options.label: B
options.text: A 14-line poem that usually follows a specific rhyme scheme.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of poetry that doesn't follow a specific rhyme or meter.

options.label: D
options.text: A poem that only explores themes of love and mortality.

multiple-choice.question: Who is a famous poet known for writing sonnets?
What is a haiku?

options.label: A
options.text: A 14-line poem that usually follows a specific rhyme scheme.

options.label: B
options.text: A short, three-line poem that originated in Japan.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of poetry that doesn't follow a specific rhyme or meter.

options.label: D
options.text: A poem that only explores themes of nature.

multiple-choice.question: What is the typical syllable count of a haiku?
What is free verse?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of poetry that follows a specific rhyme and meter.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of poetry that doesn't follow a specific rhyme or meter.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of poetry that only explores themes of identity and social justice.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of poetry that is only written by modern poets.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the benefits of writing in free verse?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows the poet to express themselves freely without adhering to any specific form.

options.label: B
options.text: It requires the poet to follow a specific rhyme and meter.

options.label: C
options.text: It only allows the poet to explore themes of identity and social justice.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only suitable for modern poets.

multiple-choice.question: Who is a famous poet known for writing in free verse?
What is one of the ways that poetry can connect us to others?

options.label: B
options.text: By exploring themes such as identity and social justice.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To explore the world of poetry and its various forms.

options.label: B
options.text: To discuss the benefits of writing in free verse.

options.label: C
options.text: To analyze the sonnets of William Shakespeare.

options.label: D
options.text: To examine the haikus of Langston Hughes.

title: What is hyperbole?

multiple-choice.question: What literary device is the speaker of the poem?
What is the purpose of using hyperbole in writing or speaking?

options.label: B
options.text: To exaggerate for effect and build intensity

options.label: C
options.text: To make a statement less urgent

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of hyperbole used in the poem?

options.label: B
options.text: "I'm so hungry I could eat a salad"

multiple-choice.question: According to the poem, why do authors use hyperbole?

options.label: A
options.text: To make their characters seem smaller

options.label: B
options.text: To emphasize the stature and size of their characters

options.label: C
options.text: To make their stories less interesting

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of hyperbole used to convey someone's toughness?

options.label: B
options.text: "If a rattlesnake bit Johnny Appleseed's feet, the snake would die immediately"

options.label: D
options.text: "Johnny Appleseed wore shoes all the time"

multiple-choice.question: How do marketers use hyperbole?

options.label: A
options.text: To make false claims about their products

options.label: B
options.text: To conduct actual tests to prove their products are the best

options.label: C
options.text: To exaggerate the benefits of their products to get people to buy

options.label: D
options.text: To make their products seem less desirable

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of using hyperbole in the phrase "I'm literally going to die if I don't get to go to the mall tonight"?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes the speaker seem less urgent

options.label: B
options.text: It conveys the speaker's feelings of desperation and urgency

options.label: C
options.text: It makes the speaker seem more calm

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on the speaker's message

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using hyperbole in the phrase "You've got a smile that could light up this old town"?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the person's smile seem less bright

options.label: B
options.text: To exaggerate the effect of the person's smile

options.label: C
options.text: To make the person's smile seem more dim

options.label: D
options.text: To have no effect on the person's smile

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between a literal meaning and a figurative meaning?

options.label: A
options.text: A literal meaning is when words mean something more than what they say, and a figurative meaning is when words mean exactly what they say

options.label: B
options.text: A literal meaning is when words mean exactly what they say, and a figurative meaning is when words mean something more than what they say

options.label: C
options.text: A literal meaning is when words mean something less than what they say, and a figurative meaning is when words mean something more than what they say

options.label: D
options.text: A literal meaning is when words mean something more than what they say, and a figurative meaning is when words mean something less than what they say

multiple-choice.question: Why does the speaker of the poem say that hyperbole is used "universally"?

options.label: A
options.text: Because hyperbole is only used in certain cultures

options.label: B
options.text: Because hyperbole is only used in certain types of writing

options.label: C
options.text: Because hyperbole is used in many different contexts and cultures

options.label: D
options.text: Because hyperbole is never used in writing or speaking

title: Why some people are more altruistic than others - Abigail Marsh

multiple-choice.question: What event in the speaker's life led them to become a psychology researcher focused on understanding the human capacity to care for others?

options.label: A
options.text: A personal experience of donating a kidney to a stranger.

options.label: B
options.text: A car accident where a stranger risked their life to save the speaker.

options.label: C
options.text: A traumatic event from their childhood.

options.label: D
options.text: A sudden realization about the importance of altruism.

multiple-choice.question: What is the definition of altruism according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: A voluntary behavior motivated by the desire to help oneself.

options.label: B
options.text: A voluntary, costly behavior motivated by the desire to help another individual.

options.label: C
options.text: A selfless act intended to benefit only oneself.

options.label: D
options.text: A selfless act intended to benefit only a family member.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the part of the brain that is important for recognizing fearful expressions?
According to the speaker's research, what is a characteristic of people who are psychopathic?

options.label: A
options.text: They are highly sensitive to other people's emotions.

options.label: B
options.text: They are insensitive to signs that other people are in distress.

options.label: C
options.text: They are highly altruistic and driven to acts of extreme kindness.

options.label: D
options.text: They are highly intelligent and rational.

multiple-choice.question: What is a common approach to understanding basic aspects of human nature, such as the desire to help other people?

options.label: A
options.text: Studying people who are highly altruistic.

options.label: C
options.text: Studying people who are average in their level of altruism.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker's research, what is a characteristic of people who are highly altruistic?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a smaller than average amygdala.

options.label: B
options.text: They have a larger than average amygdala.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the quality that makes people as angels, according to St. Augustine?
According to the speaker, what is happening at the societal level in terms of altruism and compassion?

options.label: A
options.text: People are becoming less accepting of suffering in ever-widening circles of others.

options.label: B
options.text: People are becoming more accepting of suffering in ever-widening circles of others.

options.label: C
options.text: People are becoming more altruistic towards family members, but less altruistic towards strangers.

options.label: D
options.text: People are becoming less altruistic overall.

multiple-choice.question: What is one possible reason why people may perceive the world as becoming worse and more cruel, despite the fact that it is actually becoming a better and more humane place?

options.label: A
options.text: Because people are becoming more aware of the suffering of strangers in distant places.

options.label: B
options.text: Because people are becoming less aware of the suffering of strangers in distant places.

options.label: C
options.text: Because people are becoming more selfish and less altruistic.

options.label: D
options.text: Because people are becoming less intelligent and less rational.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is within reach for almost everyone?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to become highly psychopathic.

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to become highly altruistic.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to remove oneself from the center of the circle and expand the circle of compassion outward to include even strangers.

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to become completely self-centered.

title: Seven continents song

multiple-choice.question: How many continents is the world split into?
Which continent has more than half of the world's population living in it?
Which river is the longest in the world and is located in Africa?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Asia, Africa, North and South America, Antarctica, Europe, and finally, Australia

options.label: D
options.text: Africa, Asia, North America, South America, Europe, Antarctica, Australia

title: Can you trust your ears? (audio illusions)

multiple-choice.question: What is the Mcgurk effect in relation to our senses?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows how our sense of touch can alter what we believe we're seeing.

options.label: B
options.text: It shows how our visuals can alter what we believe we're hearing.

options.label: C
options.text: It shows how our sense of smell can alter what we believe we're tasting.

options.label: D
options.text: It shows how our sense of hearing can alter what we believe we're seeing.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the same audio clip of "Bar Bar Bar" is played with a video showing the words "Far Far Far"?

options.label: A
options.text: The audio clip sounds the same as before.

options.label: B
options.text: The audio clip sounds like it's saying "Far Far Far".

options.label: C
options.text: The audio clip sounds like it's saying something completely different.

options.label: D
options.text: The audio clip is not affected by the video.

multiple-choice.question: What is the tritone paradox in relation to auditory illusions?

options.label: A
options.text: It's an illusion where two tones sound like they're ascending when they're actually descending.

options.label: B
options.text: It's an illusion where two tones sound like they're descending when they're actually ascending.

options.label: C
options.text: It's an illusion where two tones contain both a higher and lower frequency, and our brains have a preference for which to listen to.

options.label: D
options.text: It's an illusion where a single tone sounds like it's changing pitch.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Shepard tone illusion in relation to auditory illusions?

options.label: A
options.text: It's an illusion where a gradually climbing tune sounds like it's only continuing to climb higher and higher.

options.label: B
options.text: It's an illusion where a gradually descending tune sounds like it's only continuing to descend lower and lower.

options.label: C
options.text: It's an illusion where a single tone sounds like it's changing pitch.

options.label: D
options.text: It's an illusion where multiple sine waves are played on top of one another, creating a descending effect.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of the Shepard tone illusion on our brains?

options.label: A
options.text: Our brain notices the drop in pitch and corrects it.

options.label: B
options.text: Our brain doesn't notice the drop in pitch and the clip sounds like it's rising forever.

options.label: C
options.text: Our brain is confused by the multiple sine waves and can't determine the pitch.

options.label: D
options.text: Our brain is unaffected by the illusion.

multiple-choice.question: What factors contribute to our brain's preference for which tone to listen to in the tritone paradox?

options.label: A
options.text: Only our geography plays a role.

options.label: B
options.text: Only our language from infancy plays a role.

options.label: C
options.text: Both our geography and language from infancy play a role.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither our geography nor language from infancy play a role.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the auditory illusions presented in the video?

options.label: A
options.text: To demonstrate how our senses can be tricked.

options.label: B
options.text: To explain how music can have a profound effect on our minds.

options.label: C
options.text: To show how our brains process visual and auditory information.

options.label: D
options.text: To discuss the importance of language in shaping our perceptions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the auditory illusions presented and music?

options.label: A
options.text: The illusions have no relation to music.

options.label: B
options.text: The illusions help explain how music can have a profound effect on our minds.

options.label: C
options.text: The illusions demonstrate how music can be used to trick our senses.

options.label: D
options.text: The illusions show how music is processed differently by our brains.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the researcher who created the tritone paradox illusion?

title: The importance of setting in a story

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the setting in a story?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide background information about the characters.

options.label: B
options.text: To inform the plot, mood, and theme of the story.

multiple-choice.question: How can the setting influence the interpretation of a character's actions?

options.label: A
options.text: By providing a detailed description of the character's appearance.

options.label: B
options.text: By establishing the time and place of the story.

options.label: C
options.text: By creating a specific atmosphere that affects the character's behavior.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how the setting can affect the mood of a story?

options.label: A
options.text: A bright and sunny day can create a gloomy mood.

options.label: B
options.text: A dark and stormy night can create a hopeful mood.

options.label: C
options.text: A Cliffs side drive with a nice new ride under bright blue skies can create a mood of hopefulness and excitement.

options.label: D
options.text: A crowded city street can create a peaceful mood.

multiple-choice.question: Why do authors choose specific settings for their stories?

options.label: A
options.text: Randomly, without any consideration for the plot or theme.

options.label: B
options.text: To create a specific atmosphere or mood.

options.label: C
options.text: To establish the time and place of the story.

options.label: D
options.text: To provide background information about the characters.

multiple-choice.question: How does the setting of a cave contribute to the plot and conflict in the story of Odysseus?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides a safe and comfortable environment for Odysseus.

options.label: B
options.text: It creates a sense of freedom and exploration.

options.label: C
options.text: It sets a darker mood and allows Odysseus to hide in the dark.

options.label: D
options.text: It establishes the time and place of the story.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the setting and the theme of a story?

options.label: A
options.text: The setting has no impact on the theme.

options.label: B
options.text: The setting can inform and reinforce the theme.

options.label: C
options.text: The setting can contradict the theme.

options.label: D
options.text: The setting can create a new theme.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to consider the setting when reading a book?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it provides background information about the characters.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it establishes the time and place of the story.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it can inform the plot, mood, and theme of the story.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a minor element of the story.

multiple-choice.question: How can the setting influence the reader's interpretation of the story?

options.label: A
options.text: By providing a detailed description of the characters.

options.label: B
options.text: By establishing the time and place of the story.

options.label: C
options.text: By creating a specific atmosphere that affects the reader's mood.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how the setting can be used to create a specific atmosphere?

options.label: A
options.text: A bright and sunny day can create a gloomy atmosphere.

options.label: B
options.text: A dark and stormy night can create a peaceful atmosphere.

options.label: C
options.text: A Cliffs side drive with a nice new ride under bright blue skies can create a hopeful and exciting atmosphere.

options.label: D
options.text: A crowded city street can create a calm atmosphere.

multiple-choice.question: Why do authors need to choose settings with care?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the setting has no impact on the story.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the setting can inform and reinforce the theme.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the setting can create a specific atmosphere or mood.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the setting is a minor element of the story.

title: Why do India and China have so many people?

options.text: They have more fertile land than other countries.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Having a high population growth rate

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Researching the domestication of plants and animals.

options.label: D
options.text: Analyzing the impact of climate change on population growth.

options.text: It was pushed farther out by the solar wind

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: They are too far away from Earth

options.label: C
options.text: They are richer in heavy hydrogen than Earth water

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They formed out beyond the sun's "frost line"

options.label: C
options.text: They are rich in heavy hydrogen

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the similar levels of heavy hydrogen in carbonaceous chondrites and Earth water?

options.label: A
options.text: It suggests that Earth's water came from comets

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It suggests that carbonaceous chondrites are the source of Earth's water

options.label: D
options.text: It suggests that Earth's water is older than the solar system

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the water that turned Earth into a "blue marble"?

options.label: A
options.text: It was part of the original package

options.label: B
options.text: It was manufactured here over the eons

title: Embrace the Shake - Phil Hansen

multiple-choice.question: What caused the speaker to develop a shake in their hand?

options.label: B
options.text: Years of making tiny, tiny dots in pointillism art

options.label: C
options.text: A medical condition unrelated to art

multiple-choice.question: What was the neurologist's advice to the speaker regarding their shake?

options.label: B
options.text: To take medication to reduce it

options.label: D
options.text: To give up on art altogether

multiple-choice.question: How did the speaker adapt to their shake when creating art?

options.label: A
options.text: By working on a smaller scale with smaller materials

options.label: B
options.text: By working on a larger scale with bigger materials

options.label: C
options.text: By using a different art style that didn't require precision

options.label: D
options.text: By using technology to create art

multiple-choice.question: What did the speaker realize was the problem when they were unable to create art despite having new supplies?
What was the speaker's solution to their creative slump?

options.label: A
options.text: To try to think outside the box and come up with something completely new

options.label: B
options.text: To "get back into the box" and work within limitations

options.label: C
options.text: To take a break from art and come back to it later

options.label: D
options.text: To seek inspiration from other artists

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the speaker's experiment to create art with a dollar's worth of supplies?

options.label: A
options.text: They were unable to create anything worthwhile

options.label: B
options.text: They created something amazing and realized that limitations can drive creativity

options.label: C
options.text: They realized that they needed more expensive supplies to create good art

options.label: D
options.text: They gave up on art altogether

multiple-choice.question: What was the concept behind the speaker's "Goodbye Art" project?

options.label: A
options.text: To create art that would last forever

options.label: B
options.text: To create art that would be destroyed after its creation

options.label: C
options.text: To create art that would be sold to the highest bidder

options.label: D
options.text: To create art that would be displayed in a gallery

multiple-choice.question: What did the speaker learn from their "Goodbye Art" project?

options.label: A
options.text: That destruction is not a good way to create art

options.label: C
options.text: That letting go of outcomes and imperfections can lead to a more creative process

options.label: D
options.text: That art should be preserved at all costs

multiple-choice.question: How did the speaker's approach to creativity change after embracing their shake and working within limitations?

options.label: A
options.text: They became more focused on creating perfect art

options.label: B
options.text: They became more anxious about making mistakes

options.label: C
options.text: They became more open to new ideas and possibilities

options.label: D
options.text: They became less interested in creating art

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message about creativity and limitations?

options.label: A
options.text: That limitations can stifle creativity and should be avoided

options.label: B
options.text: That creativity requires unlimited resources and freedom

options.label: C
options.text: That limitations can actually drive creativity and lead to new ideas and possibilities

options.label: D
options.text: That creativity is only for talented people
